messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Nonobtuse triangulations of PSLGs

Paper Abstract: Abstract. We show that any planar straight line graph with nùëõn vertices has a conforming triangulation by O‚Äã(n2.5)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ2.5O(n^{2.5}) nonobtuse triangles (all angles ‚â§90‚àòabsentsuperscript90\leq 90^{\circ}), answering the question of whether any polynomial bound exists. A nonobtuse triangulation is Delaunay, so this result also improves a previous O‚Äã(n3)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ3O(n^{3}) bound of Eldesbrunner and Tan for conforming Delaunay triangulations of PSLGs. In the special case that the PSLG is the triangulation of a simple polygon, we will show that only O‚Äã(n2)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ2O(n^{2}) triangles are needed, improving an O‚Äã(n4)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ4O(n^{4}) bound of Bern and Eppstein. We also show that for any œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, every PSLG has a conforming triangulation with O‚Äã(n2/œµ2)ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ2superscriptitalic-œµ2O(n^{2}/\epsilon^{2}) elements and with all angles bounded above by 90‚àò+œµsuperscript90italic-œµ90^{\circ}+\epsilon. This improves a result of S. Mitchell when œµ=38‚ÄãœÄ=67.5‚àòitalic-œµ38ùúãsuperscript67.5\epsilon=\frac{3}{8}\pi=67.5^{\circ} and Tan when œµ=730‚ÄãœÄ=42‚àòitalic-œµ730ùúãsuperscript42\epsilon=\frac{7}{30}\pi=42^{\circ}.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Spacetime meshing with adaptive refinement and coarsening",
        "Nonobtuse triangulation of polygons",
        "Numerical schemes for the Hamilton-Jacobi and level set equations on triangulated domains",
        "Triangulating polygons without large angles",
        "Mesh generation and optimal triangulation",
        "Polynomial-size nonobtuse triangulation of polygons",
        "Provably good mesh generation",
        "Drawing the planar dual",
        "Linear-size nonobtuse triangulation of polygons",
        "Mesh generation",
        "Quadrilateral meshes for PSLGs",
        "A discrete Laplace-Beltrami operator for simplicial surfaces",
        "Solving elliptic finite element systems in near-linear time with support preconditioners",
        "On nonobtuse simplicial partitions",
        "Polyhedral embedding of a net",
        "A square acutely triangulated",
        "Maximum principle and uniform convergence for the finite element method",
        "Triangulations and meshes in computational geometry",
        "An upper bound for conforming Delaunay triangulations",
        "Computing acute and non-obtuse triangulations",
        "Quality triangulations with locally optimal Steiner points",
        "A new statistical approach to geographic variation analysis",
        "Mathematical games. a fifth collection of brain-teasers",
        "Mathematical games. the games and puzzles of Lewis Carroll, and the answers to February‚Äôs problems",
        "The dissection of a polygon into nearly equilateral triangles",
        "Elementary Problems and Solutions: Solutions: E1406",
        "Acute triangulations",
        "Acute triangulations of sphere and icosahedron",
        "Acute triangulations of flat tori",
        "Acute triangulations of the regular icosahedral surface",
        "Acute triangulations of the regular dodecahedral surface",
        "Acute triangulations of polyhedra and RnsuperscriptùëÖùëõR^{n}",
        "Nonstandard nonobtuse refinements of planar triangulations",
        "There is no face-to-face partition of ‚Ñù5superscript‚Ñù5\\mathbb{R}^{5} into acute simplices",
        "Nonobtuse remeshing and mesh decimation",
        "Acute triangulations of polygons",
        "Coping with inconsistencies: a new approach to produce quality triangulations of polygonal domains with holes",
        "Refining a triangulation of a planar straight-line graph to eliminate large angles",
        "Point placement algorithms for Delaunay triangulation of polygonal domains",
        "A new and simple algorithm for quality 222-dimensional mesh generation",
        "Delaunay edge refinements",
        "Best-case results for nearest-neighbor learning",
        "Acute and nonobtuse triangulations of polyhedral surfaces",
        "Fast marching methods",
        "Delaunay refinement algorithms for triangular mesh generation",
        "Nearly-linear time algorithms for graph partitioning, graph sparsification, and solving linear systems",
        "An optimal bound for high-quality conforming triangulations",
        "Adaptive spacetime meshing for discontinuous Galerkin methods",
        "Pitching tents in space-time: mesh generation for discontinuous Galerkin method",
        "Well-centered planar triangulation ‚Äì an iterative approach",
        "Well-centered triangulation",
        "A dihedral acute triangulation of the cube",
        "About Delaunay triangulations and discrete maximum principles for the linear conforming FEM applied to the Poisson equation",
        "Stable finite elements for problems with wild coefficients",
        "Acute triangulations of doubly covered convex quadrilaterals",
        "Acute triangulations of flat M√∂bius strips",
        "Acute triangulations of the double triangle",
        "Survey of two-dimensional acute triangulations",
        "Acute triangulations: a short survey"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Nonobtuse triangulations of PSLGs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
